fr:title.text: Linear operator is diagonalizable iff its matrix is similar to a diagonal matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear operator is diagonalizable iff its matrix is similar to a diagonal matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 11.4.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Let B be a basis of V. Then L is diagonalizable if and only if there exists an invertible matrix S\in \mathbb {F}^{n\times n} such that S[L]_{B}S^{-1}=\begin {pmatrix}\lambda _{1} & & & \\ & \lambda _{2} & &\\ & & \ddots & \\ & & & \lambda _{n}\end {pmatrix} where [L]_{B} is the matrix for L with respect to B.

fr:title.text: Adjoint of linear map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoint of linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.1
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V and W be Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be a linear transformation. Then the Adjoint (or Hermitian Conjugate) of L is the operator L^{*}\in \mathcal {L}(W,V) such that \langle L(v),w\rangle =\langle v,L^{*}(w)\rangle for any v,w\in V.
Note: in Physics literature, the adjoint of L is usually written with daggers L^{\dagger } because it's a more cut-throat audience.

fr:title.text: Self-adjoint linear map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Self-adjoint linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.10
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is Self-Adjoint (or Hermitian) if L=L^{*}.

fr:title.text: Ant-self-adjoint linear map

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is Anti-Self-Adjoint (or Anti-Hermitian) if L=-L^{*}.

fr:title.text: Normal operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Normal operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.18
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.2.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is Normal if LL^{*}=L^{*}L.

fr:title.text: Operator is normal iff norm of operator equals norm of its adjoint

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Operator is normal iff norm of operator equals norm of its adjoint
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 7.20
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 11.2.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space with a Norm. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L is normal if and only if \left \lVert Lv \right \rVert =\left \lVert L^{*}v \right \rVert for all v\in V.

We see \begin {align*} T\hbox { is normal}&\iff T^{*}T-TT^{*}=0\\ &\iff \langle (T^{*}T-TT^{*})v,v\rangle =0\hbox { for all }v\in V\\ &\iff \langle T^{*}T,v\rangle =\langle -TT^{*}v,v\rangle \hbox { for all }v\in V\\ &\iff \left \lVert Tv \right \rVert ^{2}=\left \lVert T^{*}v \right \rVert ^{2}\hbox { for all }v\in V \end {align*} Hence the result.

fr:title.text: Eigenvectors of normal operator are orthogonal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvectors of normal operator are orthogonal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 7.22
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 11.2.4

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a normal linear operator. If \lambda ,\mu \in \mathbb {C} are distinct eigenvalues of L with eigenvectors v and w (respectively), then \langle v,w\rangle =0.

We see that (\lambda -\mu )\langle v,w\rangle =\langle \lambda v,w\rangle -\langle v,\overline {\mu }w\rangle =\langle Tv,w\rangle -\langle v,T^{*}w\rangle but \langle Tv,w\rangle -\langle v,T^{*}w\rangle =0 by definition of adjoint, so (\lambda -\mu )\langle v,w\rangle =0. Since \lambda \neq \mu , this means \langle v,w\rangle =0 as desired.

fr:title.text: Linear operators on complex vector spaces have an upper-triangular matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear operators on complex vector spaces have an upper-triangular matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 5.45
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 7.5.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then there exists a basis B for V such that M(L) is upper triangular matrix with respect to B.

The basic argument is that we will consider a chain of subspaces U_{1}\subseteq U_{2}\subseteq …\subseteq U_{n-1}\subseteq V where \dim (U_{k})=k for each k=1,…,n-1 and \dim (V)=n. Moreover each U_{k} is invariant under L. Then we just need to find a basis v_{1},…,v_{n} of V such that v_{1},…,v_{k} forms a basis of U_{k}. The Criteria for linear operator to have an upper-triangular matrix implies M(L) with respect to this basis is upper-triangular.

fr:title.text: If a linear operator is upper triangular to some basis, then there is an orthonormal basis which turns it into an upper triangular matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: If a linear operator is upper triangular to some basis, then there is an orthonormal basis which turns it into an upper triangular matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 9.5.5

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}, let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. If there is some basis B of V such that L is an upper-triangular matrix with respect to B, then there exists an orthonormal basis C of V such that L is an upper triangular matrix with respect to C.

fr:title.text: Spectral theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Spectral theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 7.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 11.3.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L is normal if and only if there exists an Orthonormal Basis of V consisting of eigenvectors of L.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume L is normal. Then combining Linear operators on complex vector spaces have an upper-triangular matrix and If a linear operator is upper triangular to some basis, then there is an orthonormal basis which turns it into an upper triangular matrix implies there exists an orthonormal basis B=(e_{1},…,e_{n}) for which the matrix M(L) is upper triangular.
We can repeat this argument to find \left \lVert L^{*}e_{j} \right \rVert ^{2}=\sum ^{n}_{k=1}|a_{j,k}|^{2}=|a_{j,j}|^{2} which implies a_{i,j}=0 for i\neq j, as desired.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume the eigenvectors of L form an orthonormal basis for V. Then M(L) is diagonal with respect to this basis (since each basis vector is an eigenvector). Then M(LL^{*})=M(L)M(L^{*})=M(L^{*})M(L)=M(L^{*}L) which implies LL^{*}=L^{*}L, hence L is normal.

fr:title.text: A linear operator is diagonalizable iff its eigenvectors form a basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A linear operator is diagonalizable iff its eigenvectors form a basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 7.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 11.4.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator of V. Then L is diagonalizable if and only if there is a basis of V consisting entirely of eigenvectors of L.

fr:title.text: Orthogonal matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthogonal matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.4.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M be an n\times n matrix over a Field \mathbb {F}. We say M is Orthogonal if M^{\mathsf {T}}=M^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Unitary matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unitary matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.4.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {C}. We say M is Unitary if the conjugate transpose is its inverse \overline {M^{\mathsf {T}}}=M^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Positive operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positive operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.5.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is positive if L is self-adjoint L=L^{*}, and also \langle Tv,v\rangle \geq 0 for all v\in V.

fr:title.text: Square root of a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Square root of a linear operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 11.5

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L,R\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say R is a square root of L if L=R^{2}.

fr:title.text: Positive operator has unique square root

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positive operator has unique square root
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 7.39
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 11.5

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let L be a Positive operator on V. Then there exists a unique square root of L.
Consequently, we will unambiguously refer to \sqrt {L} for the square root of L when we know L is a positive operator.

fr:title.text: Unitary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unitary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.51

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a complex inner product space. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. We say L is Unitary if \langle Lv,w\rangle = \langle v,L^{-1}w\rangle for all v,w\in V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polar decomposition
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 7.93
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 11.6.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is analogous to writing a complex number as z=r\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta }. Here \mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta } is analogous to U, and r is analogous to \sqrt {L^{*}L}.

fr:title.text: Singular values

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Singular values
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 7.51

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V, W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear operator. The Singular values of L are the non-negative square roots of the eigenvalues of L^{*}L listed in decreasing order, as many times as the dimension of the corresponding Eigenspace of L^{*}L.
